description: In Suriname "the 'Exceptional Condition Act COVID-19' was passed unanimously on April 7 after a marathon meeting in The National Assembly (DNA)."

In Suriname, the 'Exceptional Condition Act COVID-19' will last from April 7 to July 7. 
 UPDATE: It was announced that the COVID-19 Crisis Management Team will come together as a formal task force from April 24, as part of the recently adopted COVID Exceptional Condition Act. The Exceptional Condition Act lasts until July 7.
President Desiré Bouterse announces national state of emergency in Suriname on the 10th of April.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: In Suriname, the Ministry of Finance starts from the May 18 with payment of social support from the COVID-19 Emergency Fund. This fund is for people who have a reduced or no income as a result of the COVID-19 crisis. The fund is intended to alleviate the acute distress of the least wealthy and groups hardest hit by the COVID-19 crisis.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: In Suriname, from April 30 to May 10, through the whole country there will be more controle from the Police and the National Army
type_text: They want to more police and military on the street to make sure that everybody follows the rules that the government set up to prevent the spread of covid 19. So the government, together with the national military and the police, decided to put more controlling forces on the street.

description: The Ministry of Health in Suriname, in collaboration with Youth Ambassadors, "started an public awareness campaign on hygiene at Feb. 1"
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 24th of Feb, it was announced that the Surinamese ministry and a focal point of the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO), led by the Director of Health, have assembled the National Public Health Response team (response team) to develop strategies to inform the general public and individuals entering the country about preventive actions to prevent the spread the Coronavirus.
In Suriname, on the 13th of March, The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Tourism (HI&T) calls on the entire Surinamese community not to hoard food for fear of the corona virus.

On the 14th of March, the Government of Suriname held a press conference to make the citizens aware of the state of affairs concerning the pandemic within their borders.From then on, the new National Covid-19 Management team would give the latest state of affairs at 18:00 every day.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, the Ministry of Health of Suriname, stated that awareness of COVID-19 has been increased through an ongoing communication campaign through various media channels as well as the BOG Facebook page.

On April 15th, the Surinamese government, in association with the SuNoticia news agency, has decided to post all new updates in Spanish as well as in Dutch. This is to make the information more easily understood in parts of the country that speaks only Spanish.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 16th, the director of the Bureau of Public Health announced that new policies for when it is necessary to wear a mask. She also announced that there was no spread within the community at this stage.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Suriname, it was announced on the 9th of May that from the 11th of May, the National COVID-19 Management team will have conversations with several organizations (non essential businesses, e.g. horeca, sportcentra, religious organizations, entertainment industry and public transport) about the reopening of these organizations. The COVID-19 Management team will hold talks with representatives of these sectors to consider how to move to standardization.

description: In Suriname, "from the 6th of April, the team of the 'Bureau voor Openbare Gezondheidszorg' (BOG) will personally visit all the people who are in quarantine on the 15th day of their quarantine to check if they're allowed to stop with quarantine".
